One thing to note about the particular experiment on checkers reported
in t=
he AAAI paper is that its performance level against humans was by
intention=
 not its focus.  

Rather, our aim in this paper was simply to demonstrate =
that being
able to learn from geometry provides a critical advantage.  So w=
e
intentionally evolved against a fixed heuristic benchmark with three
algo=
rithms that are all variants of NEAT.  That way, the contribution
of learni=
ng from geometry is isolated effectively, and you can see the
advantage Hyp=
erNEAT has over the other methods.  

Because the training is always run ag=
ainst a single fixed heuristic
player, there is no way that evolution can p=
roduce anything much
better than the heuristic (because no more challenging=
 players are
ever encountered during training), so whether or not the resul=
tant
player defeats humans is not that interesting (it would only indicate
=
that something slightly better than the heuristic is also better than
some =
human players, for whatever that is worth).

Yet as Jason mentioned we have=
 also run separately some coevolutionary
runs, and those the ones where it =
does become interesting what level
of human player can be defeated.  Nevert=
heless, Jeff and Derek, I
agree with your criticisms of this kind of sensat=
ional claim (e.g.
"beats masters level player!") so we need to be careful t=
o put any
such claim in context if we come to the point where we get result=
s
like that.

And Derek, thanks for the Go link, very interesting!

ken

--=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> On Thu, Ap=
r 17, 2008 at 1:26 PM, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
> >
> >  Finally, whi=
le it is cool that your program beats you guys at
checkers, it
> >  might n=
ot solely be because of the HyperNEAT-driven AI. The
program is also
> >  u=
sing alpha-beta and the like. I'll bet a rather poor position
evaluator
> >=
  plus Alpha-Beta with a decent amount of lookahead could beat me at
> > ch=
eckers, even if I was better at evaluating board positions on
average.
> 
>=
 Good point, Jeff. This was one of my big problems with Blondie24
> (althou=
gh to the author's credit, he did address the issue, along with
> many othe=
r objections). The question is the amount of work being done
> by the ANN v=
s. the brute-force approach of tree search. The Blondie24
> network did bet=
ter than a crude board estimation such as simply
> counting the number of o=
pponent and friendly pieces on the board, but
> not a whole lot better.
> 
=
> On a related note, I just saw today that the Go program MoGo beat a
> 5th=
 Dan Go professional in 9x9 play:
> 
> http://www.hpcwire.com/hpc/2278450.h=
tml
> 
> MoGo uses Monte Carlo methods, which from what I understand is a
>=
 variant of brute-force search, which I don't think sheds much light on
> h=
ow humans solve such problems and won't scale or generalize very
> well.
> =

> --Derek
>
